speaker: Mr Speaker
theText: Order! It being 11 p.m.,The following answers to questions were circulated: Taxation: Election Promises (Question No. 955) Mr Crean asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 30 September 1999: (1) Did the Coalition promise not to introduce new taxes or increase existing taxes during the 1996 election. (2) What tax rates did the Government increase and what new taxes did it introduce between the 1996 and 1998 Federal elections. (1) The Coalition policy for the 1996 election was not to introduce new taxes or increase existing taxes as a contrast to the Keating Labor Government which promised prior to the 1993 election not to increase taxes, and then after that election:Increased wholesale sales tax rates from 10%, 20% and 30% to 12%, 22% and 32%; Increased unleaded petrol excise by 5 cents per litre; Increased leaded petrol excise by 7 cents per litre (after proposing to increase it by 10 cents per litre); Increased the company tax rate from 33 to 36 per cent; and Took away the L-A-W income tax cuts that had been legislated prior to the 1993 election. (2) None Commonwealth Funded Programs: Tasmania (Question No. 1532) Ms O’Byrne asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 11 May 2000: (1) Does the Minister’s Department administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations, businesses or individuals can apply for funding in Tasmania; if so, what are the programs. (2) Does the Minister’s Department advertise these funding opportunities; if so, (a) what print media outlets have been used for the advertising of each of these programs and (b) were these paid advertisements. (1) Yes, the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts does administer Commonwealth funded programs through which community organisations, businesses or individuals can apply for funding in Tasmania. The programs are: Playing Australia, the national performing arts touring program; Contemporary Music Touring Program, which funds bands to undertake national tours; Visions of Australia, the national exhibitions touring program; Festivals Australia, which funds cultural activities at regional and community festivals; During the last three years, organisations based in Tasmania have been successful in obtaining funding from the Playing, Visions and Festivals programs. Television Fund, through which eligible community organisations can apply for funding under two components of the Television Fund:(i) Under the Television Black Spots Program community groups or local government authorities can apply for funding to retransmit ABC, SBS and commercial television services in black spot areas of poor or non-existent television reception.

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Mcgauran
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(ii) The Remote Commercial Subsidy Program is open to existing self-help retransmission groups in remote broadcast areas seeking to rebroadcast a second remote commercial television service. Community Broadcasting, In 2000-01, the Commonwealth will provide $5.407m to assist community broadcasting. These funds are allocated to the Community Broadcasting Foundation Ltd (CBF) in accordance with the terms of an annual grant agreement administered by the Department. The CBF is an independent company established by the community broadcasting sector to allocate funding assistance to individual stations and peak bodies. There are now over 190 community stations throughout Australia that are eligible to apply to the CBF for grants. Specific proportions of the annual grant are directed to community broadcasting in general and to sub-sectors with special needs: ethnic broadcasting, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander broadcasting and broadcasting for the print handicapped. Networking the Nation Networking the Nation is a Commonwealth grants program providing over $400 million in funding to not-for-profit organisations to support activities and projects designed to address a range of telecommunications needs in regional, rural and remote Australia. The different parts of the program consist of the: General Fund. Established in 1997 following the sale of the first third of Telstra. This is the original and main part of the program. Under this part of the program $250 million was allocated to the States and Territories over a five-year period commencing in 1997. Tasmania received $58 million. mote and Isolated Island Communities. This part of the Fund is providing $20 million to address the particular telecommunications needs of remote and isolated island communities. proved Internet Access. This part of the program is providing $36 million to ensure that all Australians have untimed local call Internet access, or at least the equivalent where traditional dial-up access is not feasible. Building Additional Rural Networks (BARN). This part of the program is providing $70 million to support the development of new networks and new network services and products, using innovation and leading edge technologies. $10 million is being provided to each State, with a further $10 million to be divided between the Territories. (2) Does the Minister’s Department advertise these funding opportunities; if so, (a) what print media outlets have been used for the advertising of each of these programs and (b) were these paid advertisements. Each of the following programs were advertised, in various media, including Tasmania’s print media. All advertising in the commercial media was paid advertising. Playing Australia; advertised in Hobart Mercury Contemporary Music Touring Program; advertised in Hobart Mercury, Launceston Examiner Visions of Australia; advertised in Hobart Mercury Festivals Australia; advertised in Hobart Mercury, Launceston Examiner and Burnie Advocate Television Fund Television Black Spots Program; advertised in Hobart Mercury, Launceston Examiner and Burnie Advocate Television Fund Remote Commercial Subsidy Program; advertised in Tasmanian Country The following programs did not advertise in the commercial print media: Community Broadcasting Fund The CBF did not advertise. It has a very narrow and specific client base. The CBF does provide detailed information to community stations about the availability, timing and categories of grants. Regular contact is maintained with all community stations by mail, phone and on-line. Networking the Nation The Department distributes 20,000 copies of the Networking the Nation newsletter nationally every three months. The newsletter is mailed directly to a range of community and local government organisations, including local government councils, regional community groups, area consultative committees, regional and country women’s associations, State Advisory Groups, libraries, financial counsellors, Members of Parliament, all Countrylink outlets and other parties on request. Agriculture: Fresh Produce Industry (Question No. 1668) Mr Andren asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 22 June 2000: Prior to the 1998 election did he give a commitment to a group representing apple growers from the Orange district and the then National Party candidate for Calare, that if re-elected the Coalition would hold an inquiry into the fresh produce (including apple) industry; if so, is he able to say when the inquiry will take place. I have been advised that a review to examine the options for the apple juice industry for expansion and value adding, in response to increasing apple juice imports, will be undertaken under the auspices of the national component of the FarmBis program. Goods and Services Tax: Advertising (Question No. 1694) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 June 2000: (1) Did the Commonwealth obtain permission to use music and other intellectual property of Mr Joe Cocker and Mushroom Records before the Government put to air advertisements concerning the Goods and Services Tax. (2) If not, (a) has the Commonwealth paid Mr Cocker, (b) may Mushroom Records, as owners of the intellectual property, set the price in conformance with accepted copyright industry practice, in substitution for a legal suit against the Commonwealth on grounds of breach of copyright and (c) has Mr Cocker and Mushroom Records sued or threatened to sue the Commonwealth for unpaid royalties. (3) If the Commonwealth did obtain permission, has the Commonwealth paid a sum for the use and broadcast of intellectual property in the hands of Mr Joe Cocker and Mushroom Records; if so, (a) what was the sum and (b) for what goods or services was the money spent. honourable member’s question: (1) The Commonwealth secured publishing rights to the music Unchain My Heart and broadcasting rights to the Joe Cocker recording of that song, prior to the airing of GST advertisements. (2) Not applicable (3) As previously advised to Senate Estimates, the advertising agency, Whybin TBWA, paid the following fees on behalf of the Commonwealth in regard to the use of music and broadcasting rights: Intellectual Property Company controlled Rights granted Amount Campbell Connelly The musical compoNon-exclusive, non-theatric licence to $100,000 sition Unchain My record mechanically and to use the Heart by Sharp& work in synchronisation or timed relaJames. tion with a commercial production to be broadcast for a period of 12 months. Festival Records Sound recording of Non-exclusive right and licence to syn$169,000 Pty Ltd (part of Unchain My Heart chronise and reproduce an extract of Festival Mushroom by Joe Cocker. the sound recording for broadcast purGroup) poses for a period of 12 months.

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to theSydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Crosswinds (Question No. 1746) 14 August 2000: Further to the answer to question No. 1505, (Hansard, 15 August 200, page 18964) will the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, the Australian Transport Safety Bureau and Airservices Australia be considering a definition of an acceptable safety hazard as a benchmark for their review of using the short runways at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport with up to 25 knots of crosswind; if not, against what criteria will safety considerations be evaluated. The review of operating with a crosswind of 25 knots is currently in progress. I am advised that the assessment of the acceptability of these operations is being done through an examination of international crosswind limits and an examination of overseas experience in operating airports with differing crosswind limits. Airservices Australia: Chief Executive Officer (Question No. 1760) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 14 August 2000: (1) How many nights has the current Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of Airservices Australia spent out of Australia since January 2000. (2) Which countries has the current CEO visited since January 2000. (3) What was the duration and purpose of each visit. (4) Did the Airservices Australia board approve each visit. (5) What was the total cost of this travel, including airfares, accommodation, expenses and allowances. (6) When does the employment contract of the current CEO expire. (7) Has the CEO confirmed that he will not be seeking a further term; if so, when did he advise that he was not seeking a further term. (8) What travel is planned for the CEO between now and the end of his employment contract. (9) What is the process for appointing a CEO for Airservices Australia and who has the authority to make the appointment. (10) Has the process for appointing a CEO commenced; if not, when and where will the position be advertised. (11) What is the financial value of the salary and conditions package for the CEO. (12) What will be the financial value of the employment contract offered to the next Airservices Australia CEO. Airservices Australia has advised the following: (1) 84 nights. (Breakdown is 17 nights on Airservices’ business – the remainder were on leave when the CEO returned home on his first extended leave during his five year tenure with Airservices Australia. CEO interrupted leave to attend the meetings held in Germany and Canada– referred to in response to (2). (2) Singapore, Germany, Canada and the United States (US. was a personal visit whilst on leave). (3) Singapore – Directors’ General of Civil Aviation meeting. Duration6 days.

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Germany– Civil Air Navigation Services Organisation (CANSO) 4th Annual General Meeting and 15th Information Meeting of the Directors of Air Navigation Services (DANS). Duration6 days. Canada– Air Traffic Control Association International Technical Program& Exhibits. Duration5 days. (4) Yes, since the Chairman must approve the appointment of an Acting Chief Executive whilst the CEO is away from Australia. (5) Total cost of travel (including air fares, accommodation and expenses/allowances) was $34,503. (6) 5 November 2000 (7) Yes. October 1999. (8) Return home to the United States at conclusion of contract. (9) Under the provisions of Section 34.(1) the AirServices Act 1995 the CEO is appointed by the Board of Airservices. (10) Yes. I announced the appointment of the new CEO on 14 September 2000. (11) Specific information is subject to privacy provisions however Airservices reports the remuneration of executive managers within a number of ranges in the Annual Report each year. In setting the level of remuneration the Board of Airservices consults with the Remuneration Tribunal before determining the Chief Executive Officer’s remuneration. (12) Refer to response to question 11. National Rail Corporation: Sale (Question No. 1762) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 14 August 2000: (1) Did he issue a media release dated 24 May 2000 titled Sale of National Rail Corporation to Proceed Shortly. (2) What is the timeframe for proceeding with the sale. (3) What are the sale management arrangements agreed between the shareholders to govern the terms of the sale process. (4) Will the sale arrangements be released to the public. (5) Will the process be an open tender process and who will make the decision on the preferred buyer. (6) Will public sector rail organisations be permitted to bid to purchase National Rail in their own right or as part of a consortia; if not, why not. (1) Yes (2) The sales management process has commenced. Expressions of Interest will be called for shortly and the sale is expected to be finalised by the middle of 2001. (3) The sale management arrangements under which the sale will be managed and proceed are set out in a Sale Management Agreement, agreed to by all shareholders. (4) No (5) Yes, the sale process will be an open tender process. Decisions on the preferred buyer will be made by shareholder Ministers representing the Commonwealth, NSW and Victoria. (6) No. It is considered that greater private sector investment and participation is essential to increasing the competitiveness of the rail industry. Recent reports into the rail industry, such as the Smorgon Report and Productivity Commission Report, Progress in Rail Reform, support the view that the interests of the rail industry would be best served by the sale of above-rail freight operators to private sector bidders.
title: Advertising

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Goods and Services Tax: Finance and Administration Portfolio (Question No. 1774) Mr Hatton asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 14 August 2000: (1) Is the Minister’s Department and agencies within the Minister’s portfolio compliant in respect of the Goods and Services Tax. (2) What action did the Minister’s Department and agencies within the Minister’s portfolio take to ensure that they were GST ready by 1 July 2000. (3) Is the Minister able to guarantee that no agency within the Minister’s portfolio will suffer negative impacts on its budget or services due to the GST; if not, or if the guarantee was subsequently proved incorrect, would the Minister be prepared to resign. (1) In June 2000, the chief executives of all agencies within my portfolio were asked to provide me with written confirmation that they would be able to comply with The New Tax System from 1 July 2000. I received such assurances from each agency. (2) Each agency within my portfolio took the following action to ensure that it was GST ready by 1 July 2000: Initial scoping of all activities to develop a GST implementation plan. Formation of a project team to manage implementation. Examination of contracts to determine GST implications. Registration for the Australian Business Number and for GST. Review of record keeping requirements to ensure compliance with the GST. Changes to financial systems to record and account for the GST. Analysis of effects of the GST on cash flows. Staff training (both general awareness training and tailored training for staff whose roles were directly affected by changes to systems and/or processes). Suppliers were notified of relevant issues relating to the GST. Price changes, where required, were made in accordance with the agency pricing guidelines. Each agency within my portfolio participated in the comprehensive monitoring surveys, coordinated by my Department’s whole-of-Government GST Unit, to ensure implementation milestones were met. (3) The implementation and ongoing management of tax reform by agencies is the responsibility of their respective chief executive officers or boards of management (as applicable). While the Government will continue to monitor the impact of the implementation of The New Tax System, it does not expect that the reforms will reduce agency funding in real terms. Transport: Disability Standards (Question No. 1784) August 2000: (1) Did the Commonwealth, State and Territory Transport Ministers sign draft transport standards under the Disability Discrimination Act in April 1999. (2) If so, have the standards been gazetted; if not, why not. (1) The Commonwealth, State and Territory Transport Ministers did not sign draft transport standards under the Disability Discrimination Act in April 1999. What they did do was to endorse the Disability Standards for Accessible Public Transport (the Standards) in April 1999 and recommend some changes to be made to the Standards. (2) The Standards will be amended and tabled before Parliament as a disallowable instrument.
title: Advertising

speaker: Mr Fahey
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Advertising

speaker: Mr Mcmullan Asked The Minister For Transport And Regional Services, Upon Notice, On 14
title: Advertising

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Transport: Adelaide Freight Terminal (Question No. 1785) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 14 August 2000: (1) Has an environmental impact statement been undertaken for National Rail’s Adelaide Freight Terminal and shunting facility at Islington and its impact in neighbouring residential areas, including Kilburn. (2) Has the Government considered funding a buffer zone at Kilburn to assist in the noise problem; if so, what was the nature and cost of the proposal. (3) Will documents to potential purchasers relating to the proposed sale of National Rail refer to the environmental difficulties associated with the operation of the Islington Depot and the community campaign for a buffer zone, including its cost. (4) What environmental impact will any extension of the Islington freight terminal have on the surrounding community as a result of work arising from the development of the Alice Springs to Darwin line. (1) National Rail (NR) advises that independent contamination audits have been undertaken at the Adelaide Freight Terminal. Ongoing noise testing is being undertaken at the perimeter boundaries and terminal staff meet regularly with concerned locals. (2) No. (3) Bidders for NR will have made available to them all reasonable information necessary to make an informed bid for the company. A vendor due diligence process is currently underway, and this will incorporate a review of all material environmental issues at NR. Islington Depot will be reviewed as part of this process and if it is determined as a material issue, relevant information will be provided in the bidder due diligence phase of the process. (4) The Government is not aware of any plans to extend the Islington freight terminal. Waterfront: Stevedoring Efficiency (Question No. 1797) Mr Danby asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 15 August 2000: (1) With regard to Patricks dispute with the Maritime Union of Australia, is he able to say whether the Prime Minister told the 1998 New South Wales Liberal State Conference that Australia’s export future was at stake. (2) What was the cost of a dry container on the (a) Melbourne-Singapore, (b) Melbourne-Hong Kong, (c) Melbourne-Bangkok and (d) Melbourne-Seoul runs (i) prior to the dispute and (ii) in October 1999. (3) What was the cost of dry container on the routes referred to in part (2) in August 2000. (4) Has the peak Australian shippers association said that despite the Government’s professed concerns at export costs that Australian exports had not had a cent in benefits from increased stevedoring efficiency. (5) In the period since January 1998 to July 2000, has Lang Corporation’s share price risen from $1.16 to $9.09. (6) During the period referred to in part (5), what benefits have accrued to Australian importers or exporters as the result of drops in the cost of stevedoring. (7) Did he meet Lord Sterling, Chairman of P&O, when he was in London for the Centenary of Federation celebrations; if so, did he raise with Lord Sterling the possibility of passing on some of the cost savings of waterfront reform to Australian importers and exporters; if no, why not.
title: Advertising

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(1) Yes. The Prime Minister in a speech to the New South Wales division of the Liberal Party on 3 April 1998 stated: “It will be important that you continue to give us, and those involved in these events, your wholehearted support because Australia’s export income future is at stake. The potential jobs of thousands of Australians are involved and the economic reputation and the reliability of this country as seen by the rest of the world is very much involved.” (2) and (3) Actual freight rate levels in liner shipping are a commercial in confidence matter, and can vary between individual shipping lines and their clients, depending on factors such as the nature, value and volume of the cargo, and the regularity of shipments. However, information in the Productivity Commission’s report on International Liner Cargo Shipping (15 September 1999) indicated that the general trend in freight rates for Australian exports had been downward in the past decade. In a number of cases rates were reported to have fallen to levels that were commercially unsustainable in the long term. For example, information from the liner shipping industry indicates that between 1995 and 1999 export freight rates fell in real terms by about 10% in the European trade, by about 13% in the North American trade, by about 28% in the North Asia trade, and by about 50% in the South East Asia trade. These decreases in freight rates were largely due an oversupply of shipping. The larger falls in the Asian trades reflect the added factor of the Asian economic crisis. Since mid 1999 there has been a recovery in freight rates, but in general these are reported to be still below the 1995 levels in real terms. Stevedoring charges make up only a minor proportion of the freight rates paid by export shippers. On 27 August 1999 in response to a question from Senator O’Brien of the Senate’s Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee as to whether there has been an overall increase or decrease in stevedoring charges since the beginning of 1998, Patrick Stevedores CEO Mr Chris Corrigan stated: ‘The facts are that our stevedoring charges have declined’. (4) The Australian Peak Shippers Association (APSA) has on a number of occasions claimed that freight rates have not been reduced as a result of the Governments recent waterfront program. Shippers have received benefits from the Government waterfront reform program through the marked improvement in stevedoring performance within Australia’s key container ports. The June 2000 issue of the Bureau of Transport Economics publication Waterline reported that the five-port average crane rate reached a record 20.4 containers per hour for the March quarter 2000. This compared with 19.1 containers per hour for the December quarter 1999. The rates at which the stevedores work ships also reached new records due to better utilisation of quay cranes. The five-port net ship rate was 31.8 containers per hour for the March quarter 2000, well above the pre-Patrick dispute figure of 24.3 containers per hour. Berth availability also reached a new high point of 94 per cent, which is just short of the Government’s reliability benchmark of 97 per cent. (5) Yes. (6) Refer to answer in question (4) above. (7) Yes. I met Lord Sterling while in London earlier this year. Our discussion covered a range of issues relating to P&O Ports activities in Australia including the recent waterfront reform process. Roads: Funding (Question No. 1808) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 15 August 2000: (1) What is the current share of national road funding received by Victoria. (2) Has Victoria’s share changed over recent years; if so, by what sums has it changed.
title: Advertising

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s questions is as follows:(3) How long does the existing agreement for the division of national road funding last. (4) What is the process by which roads are declared Roads of National Importance. (5) On how many occasions during the period 1993-1999 did the Victorian Government seek to secure with the Federal Government an agreement over any Roads of National Importance. (6) What was the first occasion in which the Victorian Government requested the Federal Government to agree to declaring the Scoresby Freeway a Road of National Importance. (7) Has the Federal Government refused to fund the Scoresby Freeway project. (1) Victoria’s current National Highway and Roads of National Importance allocation totals $95.13m from a total national allocation of $816.84m. (2) Victoria’s funding share, as with all States and Territories, changes on an annual basis. For example, in 1998/99 Victoria’s share of National Highway and Roads of National Importance was $107.4m from a total national allocation of $874.5m. In 1999/2000 Victoria’s share was $84.7m from a total national allocation of $815.4m. Victoria’s allocations for the years 2001/02 and 2002/3 are forecasted to increase to $220.8m and $205.9m respectively, depending on the ability of the Victorian Government to bring proposals to the point where tenders can be called. (3) Road funding is based on competing priorities on a National basis and not on a predetermined States share agreement. Projects are assessed on their merits and focussed on those areas of the network where the largest net benefit can be achieved. (4) Roads of National Importance can be nominated by State Governments or by specific interest groups. The broad criteria when designating Roads of National Importance is that the project is not on the National Highway system and that it will return significant economic benefit to the nation. (5) The Roads of National Importance program started in 1996. The Victorian Government has sought funding for Roads of National Importance annually as part of their general road funding submission. (6) Since the early 1990s the Victorian Government has sought to secure funding for the Scoresby Freeway. Under the Roads of National Importance program. Victoria has sought declaration since 1996. (7) Development of the Scoresby Corridor is the responsibility of the Victorian Government. The Federal Government, for its part, is prepared to discuss with Victoria how best construction of the Scoresby Corridor might be funded. The release of the Partnerships Victoria paper by Victoria provides an ideal policy platform from which private sector development of Scoresby could be pursued. Information relating to the movement records of former Senator Colston during 1999 are not currently of interest to the AFP and hence are not matters relating to law enforcement.

(2) Was any of the cost recoverable from the-organisers of the race, the Cruising Yacht Club of Australia; if not, why not. (1) The Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) arranged and paid for the use of civil resources for search and rescue operations for the Sydney-Hobart Yacht Race during the period 27-29 December 1998. The total cost to AMSA was $697,101.40. (2) None of the costs were recovered. Search and rescue services are provided by AMSA in pursuance of the AMSA Act and in accordance with relevant maritime and aviation international conventions. The .conventions are based on the humanitarian principle of rendering assistance to those in distress without regard to their origins. Successive Australian Governments have accepted that funding for search and rescue services is provided as a community service obligation. This accords with the worldwide practice of signatories to the conventions. speaker: Mr Mcgauran
theText: The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts(1) Will the Minister bring up to date the information that he provided in the answer to Question No. 48 (Hansard, 1 March 1999, page 3700). (2) When did he receive the text of the recommendations of the British House of Commons Culture, Media and Sport Committee relating to the care and safe-keeping of Indigenous remains and to the handling of requests for their return. (3) What communications have he and his Department had with their British counterparts on this issue. the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) In undertaking its responsibilities regarding the repatriation of cultural property from overseas, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) has been in contact with the University of Edinburgh in the UK regarding Australian Indigenous human remains held in that institution. The University of Edinburgh cooperated with ATSIC and the Australian High Commission in London to return the skeletal remains of approximately 330 Indigenous individuals to Australia in June this year. the Polish Government and museum authorities for the return of an Indigenous human skeleton held by the Kornik Museum in Poland. Earlier this year, the Museum was said to be agreeable to the return of these remains to Australia but subsequently changed its position and has indicated that ongoing scientific research does not permit handing over the skeleton in the near future. (2) The recommendations were published on 25 July 2000 and made widely available on the Internet and I did not have access to them before that time. (3) During the last year there have been ongoing discussions between the Australian and British governments aimed at developing a cooperative approach to dealing with the repatriation of Indigenous human remains from Britain. In June 2000 I made a submission on this issue to the House of Commons Culture, Media and Sport Committee inquiry into Cultural Property: Return and Illicit Trade. The Australian and British Prime Ministers issued a joint statement on 4 July 2000 that outlined their governments’ commitment to increasing efforts to repatriate human remains to Australian Indigenous communities. theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(2) Is it also the case that since 1 July 1998 people leaving Australia permanently have been unable to access their superannuation before retirement unless their holdings are $200 or less; if so, why. (3) Is he aware that as a result of the changes (a) young people leaving Australia with small superannuation holdings risk losing track of their superannuation altogether or having it eroded by fees and charges and (b) may be unable to access their superannuation for 30-40 years. (4) Will the Government consider reforming the superannuation early access rules to allow amounts held by Australians leaving the country permanently to be rolled over into a complying fund in the country the claimant moves to; if not, why not. honourable member’s question: (1) (a) and (b) Yes. (2) Generally, yes. Early release of preserved benefits is possible, subject to the governing rules of the fund, if the benefits are taken in the form of a lifetime non-commutable pension or annuity, are restricted non-preserved benefits, or on compassionate grounds in certain limited circumstances. The purpose of the superannuation preservation rules is to ensure that superannuation savings that have benefited from Australian tax concessions are used to provide income in retirement and not for other purposes. (3) (a) “Member protection rules” are in place to ensure that fees on superannuation accounts with balances below $1,000 do not exceed investment gains. (b)The superannuation preservation rules are to ensure that superannuation savings are used to provide income in retirement. (4) The Government has announced that it would be prepared to negotiate arrangements with other countries on a reciprocal basis to allow non-residents to transfer their superannuation entitlements to an approved pension fund in their home country. Airports: Runway Debris (Question No. 1950) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 7 September 2000: (1) Are there Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) regulations governing the regularity of checking and clearing debris and objects from runways at Australia’s capital city and major regional airports, if so (a) how often are checks required, (b) does CASA conduct audits to ensure airport compliance with CASA runway inspection regulations, (c) how many audits have been conducted since 1995, and at which airports have they been conducted and (d) have there been any prosecutions or show cause notices issued to airport operators with respect to the runway inspection regulations since 1995. (2) Is the airport owner or operator responsible for ensuring the checks occur. (3) Do airport operators record the frequency of runway checks. The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has advised the following: (1) Yes. Civil Aviation Regulation (CAR) 89H requires the operator of a licensed aerodrome to have an aerodrome manual, and CAR 89I states that the information which must be included in the aerodrome manual is shown in Schedule 10 of the CARs. All capital city aerodromes are licensed. All regional aerodromes which are used by regular public transport (RPT) aircraft with a seating capacity exceeding 30 passengers must also be licensed and all aerodromes may apply to be licensed regardless of the presence or size of RPT operations. Schedule 10 requires the operator of a licensed aerodrome to include, in the aerodrome manual, information about the aerodrome as well as the arrangements that are in place to ensure that safety is maintained. These include details of the arrangements for carrying out inspections of the movement area (including runways), arrangements for keeping records of the inspections, frequency of the

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the
title: Atsic Has Also Been In Touch With The Australian Embassy In Warsaw Which Has Negotiated With

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:inspections, an inspection checklist, arrangements for reporting and correcting any unsafe conditions and the names and roles of the aerodrome staff who are responsible. (a)Chapter9 of the CASA publication "Rules and Practices for Aerodromes" contains details of aerodrome inspection requirements, including the frequency of inspections. At aerodromes with 24 hour Air Traffic Control (ATC), inspections are required each day as soon as practicable after first light, after significant weather phenomena such as strong winds or heavy rain, and when requested by ATC. At other aerodromes, inspections are required each day before the first daylight public transport service movement, after significant weather phenomena such as strong winds or heavy rain, and when requested by Airservices Australia or CASA. Aerodrome operators may exceed these minimum requirements and CASA can direct an aerodrome operator to alter the procedures using CAR 89M if required to ensure the safety of aircraft. (b)Yes. CASA employs 12 Aerodrome Inspection staff who conduct audits of all licensed aerodromes in accordance with the Aviation Safety Surveillance Program (ASSP). The audits include all aspects of the procedures in the aerodrome manual, including aerodrome inspections. (c) There are approximately 260 licensed aerodromes in Australia, which are all audited on a regular basis in accordance with the ASSP. The program specifies an audit each 12 months for aerodromes which are used by RPT aircraft with more than 9 passenger seats and each 24 months for all other licensed aerodromes and for unlicensed aerodromes which are used for RPT operations. (d)No. There have been no prosecutions or Show Cause Notices issued to aerodrome operators in relation to runway inspections since 1995. (2) Yes. The aerodrome operator is responsible for ensuring that the checks occur. CAR 89M states that the aerodrome operator must operate and maintain the aerodrome in accordance with the procedures set out in the aerodrome manual. (3) Yes. The aerodrome manual must include details of the frequency of checks, the checklist used and a logbook or other system for recording inspections. Foreign Aid: Microcredit Funding (Question No. 1976) (1) What increase in funding for microcredit has been included in the 2000-2001 aid budget. (2) Is the additional funding supporting lending to the poorest people. (3) Is the funding being used to enable non-government organisations to distribute assistance to individual microcredit programs. (1) The Australian Government remains committed to doubling microfinance expenditure through the aid program within the life of the current Parliament, consistent with ensuring a high quality portfolio of activities. In support of this commitment I announced in the 1999-2000 Commonwealth budget, a three-year $3 million fund to act as a catalyst for further assistance to the microfinance sector in partnership with developing countries in our region. There has been no specific budget allocation for microfinance apart from this seed fund. This reflects the fact that the Government’s microfinance commitment will be met by increasing the role of microfinance in its regular programs, not by introducing a separate allocation specifically for microfinance. The role of the seed fund is to facilitate this process. It is only if we succeed in giving microfinance a more secure and prominent role in AusAID regular bilateral and NGO programs that a long-term enhancement of Australia’s contribution to the development of microfinance will be assured. A lot of work has been done and will continue to be done, much of it independently of the seed fund, to consolidate and expand the role of microfinance in Australia’s aid program (2) AusAID’s microfinance projects target those among the poor who are able to make effective use of credit. Consequently, there is a strong focus on women, given their disproportionate representation

Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund: Estimates (Question No. 1982) Mr Tanner asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 3 October 2000: (1) What are the forward estimates for (a) 2000-2001, (b) 2001-2002, (c) 2002-2003 and (d) 20032004 for the Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund. (2) What sum has been committed to projects for each year referred to in part (1). has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) The present Networking the Nation (NTN) program was originally established as the $250m Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund (RTIF) over five years from 1997-98 and funded from the sale of the first third of Telstra. This is now referred to as the NTN General Fund. An additional $171m Social Bonus funding from the sale of the next 16% of Telstra was provided for initiatives including: The Local Government fund ($45m over five years from 1999-2000) to assist local government authorities in regional Australia to provide online access to information and services including the Internet– this funding is not incorporated into the RTIF; Building Additional Rural Networks ($70m over five years from 1999-2000) to promote ongoing, sustainable improvements in regional telecommunications services – this funding is not incorporated into the RTIF; The Internet Access fund ($36m over three years from 1999-2000) to stimulate Internet service delivery in regional and rural Australia – this funding is incorporated into the RTIF; The Remote and Isolated Islands fund ($20m over three years from 1999-2000) to improve telecommunications access for remote island communities – this funding is incorporated within the RTIF. Social bonus funding for Mobile Phones on Highways ($25m over three years from 1999-2000) is incorporated within the RTIF but will be allocated through a competitive tender process and not through the NTN Board process as applies to the other initiatives outlined above. The objective of this initiative is to deliver mobile service to the maximum number of users of the designated highways, and any additional highways, regardless of where these users normally reside or do business. Oil: New Production Technologies (Question No. 2006) Dr Theophanous asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 3 October 2000: (1) What efforts are being made to implement new technologies that would serve to loosen the grip that oil companies have on the Australian motorist. (3) Is the Government prepared to follow the lead of other nations such as the USA and implement an initiative which would promote clean fuel-burning and also serve to help sugar farmers who could sell their sugar cane to produce the ethanol needed for E-85.

speaker: Mr Moore
theText: The Minister for Industry, Science and Resources has provided the followinganswer to the honourable member’s question: (1) The Government is providing significant support for the development of alternative fuels. Ethanol, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), and compressed natural gas (CNG) have been included in legislation as alternative fuels which are excise exempt. The excise exemption represents a cost to revenue of some $700 million each year. It provides a 38 cent per litre cost advantage compared to petrol and diesel. The Government, through the Australian Greenhouse Office has an integrated strategy to encourage the use of cleaner alternative fuels through three programs: The Alternative Fuels Conversion Program The CNG (Compressed Natural Gas) Infrastructure Program The Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme The Alternative Fuels Conversion Program (AFCP) is a four year, $75 million initiative which was commenced in January 2000. The Program applies to certain heavy commercial vehicles and provides funds of up to 50 per cent of either: the difference between the purchase price of new CNG/LPG fuelled vehicles over their conventionally fuelled equivalents; the cost of converting conventionally fuelled vehicles to operate on CNG/LPG; or the cost of upgrading the fuel systems of vehicles already operating on CNG/LPG where improvements in greenhouse and other emissions can be demonstrated. The CNG Infrastructure Program (CNGIP) is a $7.6 million program designed to facilitate the establishment of a national network of CNG refuelling stations. The Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme (DAFGS) commenced in July 2000 and will maintain existing price relativities between diesel and a range of alternative fuels by allowing transport operators that are eligible for the diesel fuel grant to also be eligible for alternative fuel grants. (2) Yes. The Government is actively exploring the use of alternative fuels such as ethanol. In addition to the beneficial excise treatment of certain alternative fuels, on 20 June this year the Renewable Energy Action Agenda New Era– New Energy was launched. Under this Action Agenda the Australian Greenhouse Office has been tasked with managing the process of identifying key opportunities for the sustainable development and use of renewable transport fuels. A Renewable Transport Fuels (RTF) Working Group has been established and had its first meeting on 5 September 2000. At current levels of production of ethanol, there is insufficient supply to enable its use by all government vehicles. As a fuel its main use is as a blend stock in the production of petrol. (3) Yes, the Government has a program to promote cleaner fuels. Environment Australia (in conjunction with the Department of Industry, Science and Resources and the Department of Transport and Regional Services other agencies and the refining and automotive industries) is currently developing new cleaner fuel specifications. An important aim for the specifications is to reduce exhaust emissions. Currently, specifications for the principal transport fuels, petrol, diesel and LPG, are being developed. The Government is aware of the potential benefits to the environment and to sugar cane farmers of a competitive, robust and ecologically sustainable fuel ethanol industry. On 25 September 2000 the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, the Hon Warren Truss MP, announced the Government will fund a study, coordinated by ABARE, of the commercial viability of increasing production of ethanol by the Australian sugar industry. The Government believes it is more appropriate for the industry to make commercial decisions about the use of ethanol, rather than for the Government to impose its use through legislation.

theText: The Minister for Industry, Science and Resources has provided the followingEducation: Funding for Non-government Schools (Question No. 2066) Mr Latham asked the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 12 October 2000: (1) Did the Government appoint a Steering Committee to oversee the development of its new SES-based model for the recurrent funding of non-government schools. (2) Did three of the eight members of the Committee represent the Catholic Education Commission; if so, what are the details. (3) Given the decision of the Catholic Education Commission not to participate in the SES system, why were three of its representatives invited onto the Steering Committee. (1) The SES Simulation Project conducted in 1998 was managed by my Department with the guidance of a Steering Committee representative of non-government schools. (2) Membership of the Steering Committee included Mrs Therese Temby, National Catholic Education Commission; Mr Chris Duncan, NSW Catholic Education Commission; and Mr Frank Pegan, Victorian Catholic Education Office. (3) The purpose of the SES Simulation Project was to explore the feasibility and validity of an SES approach to funding non-government schools. Although participation in the Project was purely voluntary, every Catholic system (and almost 100 per cent of Catholic systemic schools) participated in the Project. The decision to essentially preserve category 11 funding for Catholic systems (category 10 for the ACT system) was taken independently of the simulation exercise.
